text:
hey everyone welcome to Pai's kitchen so today 
we are going to make an Indian dish now usually

when I go out to restaurants I'm not one of those 
people who like to order their regular dish every

time I like to change it up except when I go to an 
Indian restaurant I always order a couple things

every single time and this is one of them I am 
making an eggplant dish called Baingan Bharta and

my apologies if I didn't pronounce that correctly 
it's this luscious thick eggplant dish almost like

a curry but it also works as a dip it's so good 
and really easy let's get started so the first

thing you want to do is cook your eggplant until 
it's really really soft that you can do that a

couple of ways of my favorite way is to actually 
put it under the broiler until it's completely

black on the outside I'll put instructions on 
how I got this it took about 45 minutes to an

hour yes that long that's how you ensure you get 
like a nice smoky flavor the penetrates through to

the eggplant I mean if you're in a rush you can 
even microwave it but you're not going to get

that smoky flavor and now I'm just going to open 
this up and dig out the eggplant to look at that

and the end I'm going to try my best to not get 
so much ash on the flesh but the eggplant should

be super soft that you can just sort of dig it out 
with a spoon yes look at that look how soft that

is and you can totally do this in advance usually 
what I would do is if I want to cook this tomorrow

I'll roast the eggplant today put the flesh in 
the fridge so I can smell the smokiness that's

going to have so much flavor so yes I know the 
flesh doesn't look great right now but it will be

delicious super easy this is a one pot dish from 
this point onward I'm just going to heat up some

oil just enough to cover the bottom of your pot 
and then I'm going to right away go in with some

cumin seeds and I want the cumin seeds to toast 
in this oil and you see because they'll start to

bubble and crackle a little bit and once the cumin 
seeds have toasted you're going to start to smell

it in the air the colors going to darken a little 
bit make sure you keep stirring so you don't get

any pockets of you know hot spots and whatnot 
oh that looks amazing so now immediately when

it going with my ground coriander and turmeric 
and I'm only going to tell that because their

ground rose like ten seconds like I'm done so 
now we need to stop it from burning by adding

my other vegetables I've got some onions and 
that will drop the temperature right away and

make sure you don't burn your spices if you're 
working with whole spices obviously it's going

to take longer time to toast but if you're adding 
ground spices to oil it's almost instant because

it's so fine now to the onion I'm also going to 
do some garlic and ginger onion garlic and ginger

like such a good combination such a classic 
in Indian cuisine and some green chilies so

I'm using some jalapeno I did remove the pith 
and the seeds because I want to be able to add

some dried chilies as well so I'm going to get 
that stirred up and cooked up until the onion

is soft I'm going to add a little bit of salt so 
the salt will help draw out moisture will help it

soften faster so the onion is partially cooked 
is not completely soft yet but at this point I

want to add my tomatoes and adding these are roma 
tomatoes and I want to give them a chance to cook

down with everything else mmm so now the tomatoes 
are soft the onions are translucent this looks

like it would be good on fish I can visualize nice 
piece of pan fried fish with this on top now if

you want to add more spices you can I'm making a 
version that uses you know some basic spices that

most people would already have at home but if you 
want to add some garam masala you want to add some

asafoetida you've got some cool Indian spices 
you can definitely throw that in it's kind of

up to you really what flavors you're going for 
now at this point I'm going to add my eggplant

ooh and if you can choose a younger eggplant that 
would be better because there aren't as many seeds

I don't really have much of a choice when I go to 
my store it's just kind of is what it is there we

go get that mixed up and just stirring will tear 
apart the eggplant now I'm also going to ask piece

this is optional but I just love that pop of color 
and also the different texture that the peas give

I'm just doing frozen I also want to add almost 
forgot some cayenne pepper and if you're wondering

why are you adding both green chillies and cayenne 
pepper and that's because even though they're both

spicy agents they all have different flavors 
so don't think of chilies as just adding Heat

green chilies have a unique flavor dried chilies 
have another unique flavor fresh red ones have a

different flavor so when you add two then you get 
two different flavors so now this is pretty thick

I'm going to add a little liquid a little water 
so that it has time to simmer so I'm going to let

this simmer for another maybe 15 minutes to allow 
the peas to cook and all the flavors to mingle

and when the peas are to take on the stain of the 
turmeric that's kind of how you know it's getting

there now I'm also going to add a little more salt 
at this point to season the eggplant stir that in

and so this is sort of the consistency that I 
like and what I'm going to do is I'm going to

let it simmer covered so it doesn't dry you know 
when I'm not looking at turn around and it's not

like stock pot so if I keep it covered on low heat 
then I won't lose much liquid you know a little

and the time has come ooh look at that that is 
perfect consistency oh yeah and see how the peas

have now taken on a slight tint of yellow that's 
usually like my cue okay we're at least very close

of all to the flavors mingling so now you want 
to taste for salt because everybody's eggplant

size is different and onion size is different and 
for something like this you want your seasoning

to be spot-on mmm oh good that's perfect it could 
even use a little more heat but I'm going to stop

here now keep in mind you're going to probably 
put this on rice or bread or something so the

seasoning has to be pretty strong I'm going to 
finish it off with some fresh seal - mmm and that

just adds such minty cooling freshness instantly 
looks fresh gorgeous let's dish it up look at that

so the consistency is more like a dip so I love 
eating this with bread or crackers or whatever

but over rice is really good too or just as a 
side dish to other proteins that you've got oh

look how cute that is that looks so good so I've 
got some a toasted flatbread that just came out

there's not traditional nan but close enough 
I think and that's how I'm going to eat it oh

that smell love it love these slices hold the 
texture of that eggplant it's like silky and

luscious and smooth and then you bite into the 
peas and you get a little pop and just wonderful

a roll of those spices and inhuman coriander and 
turmeric are just smashes made in heaven and once

you've mixed the eggplant when you finish cooking 
the eggplant at first you smell the smokiness

really strongly but once it's mixed with all that 
spices the smokiness is mellowed out quite a bit

and it's mingled with everything and it doesn't 
taste like super smoky but you know that it has

a lot of robustness to this dish that doesn't 
have any yeah it's vegan what do you know I've

made a vegan dish transient and it's so good and 
it's super easy so if you are an eggplant lover

definitely give this one a try and if you make the 
eggplant in advance and gross with an advance it's

just a snap to make right so the recipe as always 
will be on PI system calm when you make it send

me a photo or if you have your own version of
